2) ~~Change to Windows subsystem for AtomicNETService so the console window doesn't show up~~

3) ~~Add a check for Visual Studio/Xamarin Studio on system + an info box if missing~~

4) ~~Comb through examples and add a language filter, also if C# not found on system being up info box when select C# language on New project~~

6)  ~~Verify there isn't a regression on zombie AtomicEditor.exe instances on windows~~

7) ~~Update new build windows text with new features, add a dist build flag to catch whether to show this (don't go off Jenkins build)~~

8)  ~~Fix typo in New Build window - "bug fixed" should be "bug fixes"~~

9)  ~~Default player window to be less than fullscreen/minimized, so it doesn't obfuscate editor window~~

data.title: Override CSComponent GetTypeName to return the managed type name
data.body: Otherwise, it returns "CSComponent" instead of the managed class name, which is misleading

data.title: C#: Components defined in the main project can no longer be obtained from a node
data.body:
CSComponent subclasses defined in the main AtomicProject assembly (ie in .cs files contained under Resources) cannot be obtained from a node with GetCSComponents. It appears as if these components are instantiated as instances of CSComponent class, instead of the subclass.

CSComponent subclasses defined in separate dlls are still instantiated correctly and can be obtained with GetCSComponent.

Quite likely related to this, the main AtomicProject assembly can no longer be selected as the assembly for a CSComponent in scene

data.title: Add --with-docs, --with-examples to build
data.body: Add --with-docs, --with-examples to build, all three platforms

data.title: XCode 8 and SDK updates, AtomicBuildInfo (date, time, git hash, build name)
Expose Material Shader Paramaters to C#
data.body:
Material shader parameters need some custom script bindings to be available, before adding these, use this as a case to look into more generic binding of Variant values (performance being main concern)

`void SetShaderParameter(const String& name, const Variant& value);`

data.title: Add a simple build check for common error of not having submodules initialized

[Windows] Android NDK build can hit MAX_PATH due to relative includes in Bullet
data.body: If the build path is very deep, NDK builds of native Android code will fail, seeing it in Bullet as many relative include paths being joined

data.title: Atomic C# iOS Support and build improvements

data.body: This will catch things like tabs being introduced in C#, C++, JS code (note: needs to be able to ignore ThirdParty sources, etc)

data.title: Fix components in separate dlls being available
data.body: Also exposed skeleton nodes as previously discussed

data.title: Android C# support for redistributable Atomic Editor binary builds
data.body:
1) Ensure **ANDROID_NDK** environment variable is set to your installation of the Android NDK

**Windows:** `Build_AtomicEditor.bat --with-android` 
**OSX:** `./Build_AtomicEditor.sh --with-android` 
Linux: I haven't installed or looked into the Xamarin Android C# stuff for Linux yet

2) Make sure the Xamarin Android tooling is installed in your VS2015 or Xamarin Studio installation

3)  Add "android" to your project's Settings/Project.json platforms property, for example:

``` json
{
    "name" : "AtomicBlaster",
    "platforms": ["desktop", "android"]
}
```

data.title: C# assemblies not inspected in player unless a referencing component is loaded
data.body:
C# dlls in the project are only inspected when a component is loaded in a scene or prefab with CSComponents with that dll set as their assembly. This is an issue in a case where all CSComponent subclasses from a dll are only intended to be dynamically created.

Two solutions here:
1) Scan for all dll files in all resource directories and attempt to inspect them on application start
2) Expose assembly inspection/loading in a simple API (probably acceptable, since this will be a very rare case).

data.title: [Linux] Editor does not start (main.js error)
data.body:
Tested on Archlinux using master branch from today. What i did was basically this:

```
git clone https://github.com/AtomicGameEngine/AtomicGameEngine.git
cd AtomicGameEngine
./Build_AtomicEditor.sh
./Artifacts/Build/Linux/Source/AtomicEditor/AtomicEditor
```

data.title: IsVarname() getters not being converted to C# property getters
data.body: Is*() get methods are not being added to the property accessors for generated wrappers. For example Node.Enabled is a set only property even though IsEnabled() exists

data.title: Atomic C# Updates
data.body:
- Major updates to C# project creation supporting PCL, Desktop, and Android projects
- ATOMIC_DEV_BUILD's now have full AtomicNET sources included in solution to make it easier to work on AtomicNET itself, including debugging native and managed code
- Unified script binding sources (all platforms now use the same C++/C# generated source files!)
- Atomic C# project JSON improvements, including persistent project GUID
- Settings/Project.json with support for specifying plaforms (and name of solution/compiled binaries)
- .. and much more

data.title: Option to enable HDR
data.body:
The PBR render paths require HDR to be enabled to correctly filter the IBL as shows in the images below. When HDR is not enabled the materials contain allot of rendering artifacts, ideally this should be optional as none PBR render paths will not need to enable HDR although enabling HDR will not cause any loss in quality under none PBR scenes.

With:
![with](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3044415/18357051/53836e66-75e7-11e6-934a-1292c4bf3ee9.PNG)

Without:
![without](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3044415/18357054/58abb40c-75e7-11e6-8f50-ebcea737b670.PNG)

data.title: Some CSComponent improvements, additions to math classes
Hook up Duktape debugger to debug JavaScript
data.body:
Duktape v. 1.5.x includes a debugger interface allowing for setting breakpoints, stepping through code, and inspecting variables.  Documentation on the debugger api can be found at https://github.com/svaarala/duktape/blob/master/doc/debugger.rst

The API is built in, but needs some setup in order to use it.  There is an example of exposing this through a socket interface, allowing a remote debugger to attach and walk through the code.  An example transport can be found here: https://github.com/svaarala/duktape/tree/master/examples/debug-trans-socket

In addition, there is currently a plugin for VSCode that will consume this socket interface and allow for stepping through your code through VSCode.  The plugin is located at https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=HaroldBrenes.duk-debug

I believe this should be broken out into a couple of tasks:
- [ ] Implement the duktape socket transport debug interface into the player so that it can be attached to by either the node.js based debugger provided by Duktape, or the VSCode plugin
- [ ] Determine if it's beneficial to bring the ability to debug into the core editor and then determine the best way to wire it up to the embedded Monaco editor.

data.title: Updated backers.md
JSComponent/CSComponent Fields in scene XML are referenced by hash
data.body: It would be very helpful for direct scene file editing if component fields were referenced by name instead of hash of name.

data.title: Monaco editor v.0.6
data.body: This updates the monaco editor to v0.6.  It doesn't appear to have any major enhancements other than bugfixes.  The change log for Monaco is at:  https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#060
